item.title: Disaster, Day 1
item.description:
Disaster Strikes

Some names have been changed to protect both the innocent and the guilty.

The Fall

A major snowstorm hit northern New Mexico in February. Government offices and schools closed everywhere—except at the Lab. We were given only a two‑hour delay. I went to my old office in the Ad Building to retrieve information my team lead, Denise, insisted only I had.

After passing through the booth and going “behind the fence,” I found the parking lot coated in solid ice. Wearing YakTrax, I shuffled carefully in a “penguin walk.” Even so, I slipped and fell hard. My left leg and right arm were trapped beneath me: I dislocated my left ankle, breaking both the tibia and fibula, and fractured my right radial head (elbow).

item.title: Disaster, Day 2
item.description:
Disaster, Day 2

After my accident, it was clear I had nowhere practical to recover. I would be in a wheelchair for months, yet my home was a 50‑year‑old duplex with all the bathrooms upstairs and the kitchen downstairs. That setup was impossible. The decision was made: I would be flown to Las Cruces, NM, where I could undergo surgery and rehabilitation in a more suitable environment.

Drugged‑up me, ever the private pilot and veteran OV‑1 Mohawk pilot from my Army days, thought: “Cool, I’ll get flown down in a Cessna 182 or maybe a Cessna 337. I’ll even ask to take the controls for a bit since I’m licensed and familiar with the type.”
Reality check: nope. First, I couldn’t work the rudder; second, I was so drugged up they wouldn’t have let me near the controls even if I could.
